video.title: HTTP, HTML, CSS - Intro to Computer Science - Harvard's CS50 (2018)
video.description:
Learn the basics of how the web works with HTTP, HTML, and CSS. 

This course teaches the foundations of computer science. This video is lecture 5 of Harvard University's CS50 2018 course (part 6 since the lectures start at 0).

Check out our full CS50 playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWKjhJtqVAbmGw5fN5BQlwuug-8bDmabi

🔗Notes: https://cs50.harvard.edu/x/2020/notes/5/
🔗Problem Set: https://cs50.harvard.edu/x/2020/psets/5/
🔗Source Code: https://cdn.cs50.net/2019/fall/lectures/5/src5.zip

⭐️Contents⭐️
⌨️ (00:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (00:00:49) TCP/IP
⌨️ (00:03:41) IP Addresses
⌨️ (00:08:52) URLs
⌨️ (00:09:44) DNS
⌨️ (00:10:44) Dissecting a URL
⌨️ (00:13:52) HTTP
⌨️ (00:17:57) Developer Tools
⌨️ (00:22:46) HTTP Status Codes
⌨️ (00:29:23) HTML
⌨️ (00:35:09) index.html
⌨️ (00:40:24) image.html
⌨️ (00:42:58) link.html
⌨️ (00:48:38) paragraphs.html
⌨️ (00:50:51) headings.html
⌨️ (00:51:42) table.html
⌨️ (00:53:22) HTML Validation
⌨️ (00:54:26) Implementing Google
⌨️ (01:00:30) CSS
⌨️ (01:01:06) css0.html
⌨️ (01:06:42) css1.html
⌨️ (01:08:28) css2.html
⌨️ (01:11:00) css3.html
⌨️ (01:12:33) css4.html
⌨️ (01:16:45) JavaScript
⌨️ (01:20:41) DOM
⌨️ (01:22:45) hello0.html
⌨️ (01:23:35) hello1.html
⌨️ (01:32:44) background.html
⌨️ (01:38:13) size.html
⌨️ (01:40:41) blink.html
⌨️ (01:43:03) geolocation.html

Lecture taught by David J. Malan. Thanks to Harvard's CS50 for giving us permission to post this lecture. Checkout their YouTube channel for more great lectures: https://www.youtube.com/cs50

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: Steven Barnes
topLevelComment.text: "When Google gets a virtual envelope" Why would Google be receiving IP addresses? Google is not the internet, it is a search engine. Admittedly, it is an excellent search engine but it is just a website where you can search for what you are looking for.

replies.author: Manas Mahanand
replies.text: Any website on the internet, including google search engine is being called using an ip address. The literal address of google. So when you search for something on google, you are sending a virtual envelope to the ip address of google, and you will be expecting a reply, which in this case is the search results

topLevelComment.author: Paul McCann
topLevelComment.text: The geolocation script at the end has a bug. If the script doesn't get the right precision argument (or has other errors) it defaults to nearest thing it can figure out – in this case the country it's in. So it puts the lat/long in the middle of the USA as a default. So that's why it points to Kansas. There's lots of stories about the unfortunate people who happened to live on the farm at that default being accused of all kinds of crimes because stupid investigators thought they knew how to geolocate an IP address.
